children.name: to leave quickly in order to avoid trouble, danger etc
run away
children.definition: / run off
examples: They ran off as soon as they heard the police car coming.

children.name: run off/away to
examples: My brother ran away to South America to escape his debts.
Zimmerman was so scared, he just ran off.
Why did you run off like that? Was Joey nasty to you?

children.name: shoot off
children.definition: UK informal to leave a place very quickly, often in order to avoid a difficult situation:
examples: Arthur shot off before anyone could say anything.
I’ve really got to shoot off - I said I’d be home ten minutes ago.

children.name: not see sb for dust
children.definition: UK informal if you do not see someone for dust, they leave somewhere very quickly in order to avoid sth, especially sth that they should stay for: không còn thấy mặt mũi ai đâu
examples: If you tell him it’s his turn to buy the drinks, you won’t see him for dust!

children.name: make yourself scarce
children.definition: informal to quickly leave a place when sth embarrassing or awkward is likely to happen: chuồn, lẩn
examples: You’d better make yourselves scarce before the manager gets here.
When Gary and Clare began to argue, Reg decided to make himself scarce.

children.name: escape
children.definition: when someone escapes from prison, from danger, or from someone who is chasing them:
examples: The girl had no chance of escape.
Christina hoped it wouldn’t be too long before she couldmakeherescape.

children.name: plan an escape
examples: We planned our escape carefully and waited for just the right moment.

children.name: prevent an escape
children.definition: alsofoil an escapeformal
examples: (= stop an escape )Walker grabbed her firmly by the wrist, preventing any chance of escape.

children.name: make your escapeformal
children.definition: to escape
examples: I had to make my escape before the guards returned.

children.name: an escape attempt/bid
examples: She made several unsuccessful escape attempts before finally getting away.

children.name: an escape plan
examples: You should have an escape plan in the event of a fire.

children.name: an escape route
examples: All their escape routes had been blocked.

children.name: have a narrow escape
children.definition: to only just avoid danger or difficulties
examples: thoát trong gang tấc

children.name: have a lucky escape
examples: We had a lucky escape when a tree crashed through the ceiling.

children.name: have a miraculous escape
children.definition: be extremely lucky to escape
examples: Ellie had miraculous escape after a firework exploded in her hand.

children.name: a means of escape
children.definition: a way of escaping
examples: She searched in vain for a means of escape.

children.name: a chance/hope/possibility of escape
examples: The river offered our only hope of escape.

children.name: make good your escapeliterary
children.definition: to succeed in escaping
examples: Dillinger handcuffed the deputy to the desk and made good his escape.

children.name: escape from
examples: Until his escape from the camps, he was beaten nearly every day by his captors.

children.name: narrow escapewhen you only just escape from danger thoát trong gang tấc
examples: It was a narrow escape - a couple of minutes later the whole place went up in flames.
The team had a narrow escape from relegation last season.

children.name: the firm’snarrow escapefrom bankruptcy
examples: Theyhadalucky escapewhen a car crashed into the front of their house.

children.name: breakout
children.definition: /jailbreakUS  an escape from a prison, especially one that involves several prisoners and is done using violence: vượt ngục
examples: ▪ Prison governors met today to discuss ways of preventing similar breakouts in the future.
▪ As many as 20 guards may have been involved in the jailbreak.

children.name: breakout from
examples: There was a mass breakout from a city center prison yesterday.
There has been a mass breakoutfromone of Germany's top security jails.

children.name: to escape from swh where you are in danger
escape
children.definition: to get away from a place, country etc where you are in danger, especially when it is difficult to do this because sb is trying to catch you or stop you leaving: trốn thoát
examples: ▪ Only four people managed to escape before the roof collapsed.
▪ The refugees have crossed miles of desert to escape civil war and famine.

children.name: escape from
examples: ▪ Josie managed to escape from her attacker and call the police.

children.name: escape into/through/over etc
examples: ▪ Some people were able to escape over the border into Tanzania.
▪ When the army began killing civilians in the town, he was able to escape through the jungle.

children.name: get out
children.definition: to escape from a place or country when there is a serious risk that sth bad will happen very soon : thoát khỏi , ra khỏi
examples: ▪ Eventually we realized there was no way of getting out.
▪ A few people managed to get out before the government crackdown.
get out of
▪ All US tourists and journalists are being advised to get out of the country as soon as possible
get out alive
▪ The whole building was on fire - we were lucky to get out alive!

children.name: run away
children.definition: /run off to try to escape from sb by running away : chạy đi bỏ chạy
examples: ▪ Don’t run away - I’m not going to hurt you.
▪ Delia managed to get away from the man and ran off screaming.

children.name: run away/run off from
examples: ▪ If you run away from the bull, it’s almost certain to attack you.

children.name: run away/run off into/down/across etc
examples: ▪ He jumped out of the car and ran off into the woods.

children.name: bolt
children.definition: to suddenly run away very quickly, as soon as you have a chance, especially because you are very frightened: lao đi
examples: One of the horses got into a panic and bolted.
When police approached him to ask him some questions, he bolted.

children.name: bolt across/into/out etc
examples: Before I could say a word, she turned and bolted out the front door.

children.name: run for it
children.definition: /make a run for itC2  informal to suddenly run away very quickly because you are in danger of being caught, especially when you are doing sth illegal: chạy đi, trốn đi
examples: Somebody’s coming. Quick, run for it.
There’s no way we can beat them - we’re going to have to make a run for it.

children.name: flee
children.definition: to escape as quickly as possible because you are in great danger - used especially in newspapers: bỏ chạy, bỏ trốn
examples: ▪ When police arrived, the two men fled.

children.name: flee from/to/into etc
examples: ▪ Most of the women there were Somalis fleeing from the civil war.
▪ Up to five million political refugees have fled to other countries.

children.name: flee the country/the city etc
examples: ▪ Rollins tried to flee the country but was stopped at the airport.

children.name: make your escape
children.definition: to escape from a place or a dangerous situation, especially when you do this quickly and secretly, as soon as you have a chance: trốn thoát
examples: He made his escape by climbing through the window and down the fire escape.
The hostages spent days waiting for the opportunity to make their escape.

children.name: take to your heels
children.definition: to escape by running away very quickly - used especially in stories: bỏ chạy
examples: ▪ The kids immediately took to their heels as Mrs Brewster appeared around the corner.
▪ He jumped off the train, took to his heels, and was quickly out of sight.
When they saw the soldiers coming, they took to their heels.

children.name: break free
children.definition: / break away to escape from b who is holding you: thoát ra
examples: ▪ She wanted to break away, but his grip was too strong.
▪ With a violent twist he broke free and ran out of the room.

children.name: break free/break away from
examples: ▪ Then Tammy broke free from Judd and ran for the door screaming.

children.name: to escape from a prison or where you are being kept
get out
children.definition: / break out to escape from a prison or from a building or room where you are being kept: thoát ra, trốn ra
examples: ▪ Some of the men were planning to break out.
▪ The doors and windows are all firmly locked - I don’t know how we’re going to get out.

children.name: break out/get out of
examples: ▪ In 1998 the two men broke out of jail and murdered a police officer.
▪ No one has ever managed to get out of this prison alive.

children.name: escape
children.definition: to escape from a prison or from a place where sb is keeping you: thoát, khỏi, trốn khỏi
examples: ▪ Guards have been ordered to shoot anyone trying to escape.

children.name: escape from
examples: ▪ He escaped from prison in June, but was rearrested by police a month later.
escape into/through/out etc.
▪ Grant had escaped through a bathroom window while in police custody.

children.name: to successfully escape from sb who is chasing you
escape
children.definition: to succeed in escaping from sb after doing sth wrong or illegal without being caught: trốn thoát
examples: It looks as if they’ve escaped. They’re probably over the border by now.
Police surrounded the building, but somehow the gunman managed to escape.
So far the terrorists have managed to escape the police.
escape[C] C1
The gang had planned their escape thoroughly.

children.name: escape from
examples: He ducked down an alley to escape from the mob that was chasing him.
Police surrounded the building, but somehow the gunman managed to escape.
He was one of nine men who escaped from prison in July.

children.name: escape into/across/over etc
examples: Criminals generally know their neighborhood well, so it’s not difficult for them to escape into the back streets.

children.name: escape through/by etc
examples: Four prisoners escaped through a hole in the fence.

children.name: escape with
examples: Thieves escaped with jewelry and $130,000 in cash.

children.name: give sb the slip
children.definition: informal to escape from sb who is chasing you by tricking them or doing sth unexpected: trốn thoát, đi khỏi, “cho ai trượt chân”
examples: Watch him very carefully - he might try and give us the slip.
I wanted to talk to her before she left the hotel, but she gave me the slip.

children.name: get away
children.definition: to succeed in leaving after doing sth wrong or illegal, especially after being chased.Get awayis more informal thanescape: thoát khỏi
examples: We ran after the mugger as fast as we could, but he got away.
He got away down a back alley.
The robbers got away but left plenty of clues at the scene.
Don’t let him get away!
How could you let him get away!
Police believe the gunmen got away in a white Ford pickup.

children.name: get away from
examples: Follow that car and don’t let it get away from you.

children.name: get away with
examples: Thieves got away with silver and several valuable paintings, including one by Picasso.

children.name: get clean awayget away completely hoàn toàn thoát khỏi
examples: Detectives followed the man as far as the harbour, but then he jumped into a speedboat and got clean away.

children.name: throw sb off the scent
children.definition: to escape from sb who is chasing you or trying to find you by cleverly doing sth that makes it impossible for them to know where you are: không để lại dấu vết, đánh lạc hướng
examples: He made the calls from different pay phones around the city to throw the police off the scent.

children.name: make your getaway
children.definition: / make a getaway to successfully escape after a crime, especially in a way that you have arranged, leaving no signs to show where you are: tẩu thoát
examples: Police have found the helicopters that the terrorists used to make their getaway.
The robbers made their getaway in a stolen car, which was waiting for them outside the bank.

children.name: make a clean getaway: to escape leaving no signs to show where you are
examples: The robbers hopped into a waiting car and made a clean getaway.

children.name: shake off
children.definition: to escape from sb, especially sb who has been chasing you for a long time, for example by hiding or by going faster than them:
examples: Mailer disappeared into a dark basement, hoping to shake off the gang.
You’re going to have to drive faster if you want to shake them off.
He drove through the red lights in an attempt to shake off the police car that was chasing him.

children.name: elude
children.definition: formal to cleverly avoid being found or caught by sb, especially for a long time: trốn tránh được
examples: Despite a $25,000 reward on his head, he continues to elude the authorities.

children.name: elude capture
examples: Lt. Forney managed to elude capture by enemy forces for several weeks.

children.name: can't escape
children.definition: can’t escape/can’t get outB1  không thể trốn, thoát
examples: ▪ I’ve locked all the doors and windows - he can’t get out.
▪ Two of the children couldn’t escape, and died in the fire.

children.name: trapped
children.definition: unable to escape from a dangerous place or an unpleasant situation: bị mắc kẹt, mắc bẫy
examples: ▪ The miners have been trapped underground for three days.
▪ He was beginning to feel trapped in his job.
▪ The two trapped firefighters were rescued on the second day.

children.name: be stuck
children.definition: bestuck/biː ˈstʌk/  especially spoken to be unable to escape from an unpleasant or boring situation: bị mắc kẹt

children.name: be stuck in/with/here
examples: ▪ I don’t want to be stuck in an office all my life.
▪ I’m tired of being stuck here with the kids all day.

children.name: be cooped up
children.definition: informal to be unable to leave a place, so that you feel bored or very impatient: bị giam, bị nhốt

children.name: be cooped up in
examples: ▪ I didn’t want to be cooped up in a small hotel room, while everyone else enjoyed the sea.

children.name: be cooped up with
examples: ▪ I don’t know how she survives being cooped up with three screaming kids all day!

children.name: there is no escape
children.definition: /ðeər ɪz ˌnəʊ ɪˈskeɪp/ used to say that there does not seem to be any way of escaping from a dangerous or unpleasant place or situation: không có lối thoát
examples: ▪ Don’t even try to get out of here - there’s no escape.

children.name: there is no escape from
examples: ▪ There seems to be no escape from the noise and confusion of city life.

children.name: be imprisoned
children.definition: to be unable to escape, or feel too frightened to escape, from the place where you are or from an unpleasant situation: giam cầm
examples: ▪ Some of these old people are imprisoned in their own homes by the threat of violence on the streets.

children.name: be a prisoner U
children.definition: be a prisoner to be unable to escape, for example from a place, an unpleasant situation, or your own thoughts and opinions, so that you feel you cannot do anything to change things: “là tù nhân”
examples: ▪ The door was locked from the outside, and suddenly they realized they were prisoners.

children.name: be a prisoner of
examples: ▪ In some respects I’m a prisoner of my past - I don’t feel I can just start over.

children.name: to escape from a difficult/embarrassing /boring situation
escape
children.definition: to get out of a difficult, embarrassing, or boring situation: trốn tránh
examples: Let’s see if we can escape before the speeches start.

children.name: extricate yourself
children.definition: formal to escape from an embarrassing or difficult situation: “gỡ thoát”
examples: ▪ Once they realized that I had been lying, it was almost impossible to extricate myself.

children.name: extricate yourself from
examples: ▪ At that time, the US was on the verge of extricating itself from the unpopular war.

children.name: get away
children.definition: to get out of a difficult, embarrassing, or boring situation: trốn tránh
examples: He decided to tell me all about his trip to Majorca, and I just couldn’t get away.

children.name: talk your way out of
children.definition: to escape from an unpleasant or embarrassing situation by giving explanations, making excuses etc: nói, viện cớ chuồn
examples: I don’t know how she’s going to talk her way out of this one.
Phil never does his homework, but he always manages to talk his way out of it.

children.name: escapee
children.definition: a person who has escaped from somewhere, especially prison : người trốn thoát
examples: The escapees were recaptured after three days on the run.

children.name: escaped
children.definition: use this to describe someone who has escaped, especially from a prison: trốn thoát
examples: ▪ Police are on the lookout for three escaped prisoners.
▪ Sherwood, an escaped convict, hunted down his ex-girlfriend and killed her.

children.name: runaway
children.definition: a person who has run away, especially from their family or an institution : người bỏ trốn
examples: a teenage runaway
a charity for runaways
runaway boys
We're searching for a couple of runawaysfromthe young offenders' institution.

children.name: be on the loose
children.definition: / be at large sb who is on the loose or at large has escaped from the police or from a prison and is likely to be dangerous: tẩu thoát
examples: There’s a killer on the loose, and we’ve got to find him.
Carillo’s murderer remained at large yesterday as investigators continued their search.
Brewer escaped from prison last year and has been on the loose ever since.

children.name: be on the run
children.definition: sb who is on the run is trying to hide or escape from sb who is chasing them, especially the police: trốn thoát
examples: After the train robbery he spent three years on the run.
After a month on the run, the prisoners were finally recaptured by the police.

children.name: be on the run from
examples: Dean was a drug addict who was constantly on the run from the police.

children.name: fugitive
children.definition: sb who has escaped from the police or from danger, who has to keep moving from one place to another so that they will not be caught: kẻ bỏ trốn, kẻ tẩu thoát
examples: Porter escaped in 1995 and remains a fugitive.
fugitive from
a fugitive from Stalin’s oppressive regime
a fugitive from US justice

children.name: retreat
children.definition: to go away from a place or person in order to escape from fighting or danger or to go to a quiet safe place in order to avoid a difficult or unpleasant situation : rút lui
examples: Attacks by enemy aircraft forced the tanks to retreat ( fromthe city).
When she came towards me shouting, I retreated (behind my desk).
retreat from/ into/ to/ etc.
He took part in the retreat from Paris.
her retreat into a fantasy world of her own.
an ignominious retreat to the River Vistula.
When he's done something wrong, he retreatstohis bedroom.
Jim saw me approaching and quickly retreated down a side street.
‘You haven’t heard the last of this!’ shouted Spencer, retreating up the stairs.
